Mile 103 | June 10, 2007

Wasilik Poplar

Mile 103 | June 10, 2007

This (dead) tree is the second-largest poplar in the United States, with a diameter of 8.6 feet and standing 125.5 feet tall. It escaped logging in the early 1900s because it was deemed too big to be hauled by oxen.

Audie Murphy Monument

Mile 677 | July 19, 2007

Audie Murphy was the most decorated American solider of the second world war, made legend by his single-handed capture of a large number of German soldiers. After the war, he acted in a number of Hollywood films and died in a 1971 plane crash near this monument.

Purple

Mile 1121 | May 18, 2010

Chair with a view

Mile 1125 | May 18, 2010

What a week! Rushed from graduation on Sunday right to the trail that night. Got off to a rainy start on Monday but met Grandma, Aunt Cindy, and Uncle Mike for a delicious — and dry — dinner. Tuesday rained all through the Cumberland valley and got COLD — was just barely warm enough that night in all my clothes under the quilt. But Wednesday came bright, beautiful, and hot, along with the first dose of PA rocks — more like boulders. Had to push a little bit to get here but am bunked with Nathan in Allentown tonight, back to the trail tomorrow.

A few days too early

Mile 1138 | May 19, 2010

Pink

Smiling at Tri-County Corner

Mile 1228 | May 23, 2010

Butterfly at Allentown Shelter

Mile 1230 | May 24, 2010

Trail through the game lands

Mile 1243 | May 24, 2010

Lots and lots of company this week — the trail is packed with section- and thru-hikers and the shelters are full every night! Plenty of trail magic too! Two days of hunger were narrowly avoided when a section-hiking friend gave me a lift to the grocery store after I shipped my food to a nonexistent shop in Port Clinton. And a day later, ran into a gang of dedicated day hikers on the Pinnacle ("best view on the AT in PA," they say) in the fog and rain. We could barely see the slippery rocks, much less the view, but they loaded me up with some much-appreciated snacks. Having fun so far! Wish you were here!

Rattlesnake

Mile 1256 | May 25, 2010

Saw two rattlesnakes in as many minutes today! They were enjoying the heat; the hikers, not as much.

Watch your step

Mile 1257 | May 25, 2010

Power line maintenance on the trail... step carefully!

Morning mist

Mile 1264 | May 26, 2010

Delaware River Joint Toll Bridge Commission

Mile 1284 | May 27, 2010

About to cross the Delaware River on Interstate 80

Blue

Mile 1301 | May 27, 2010

Evening View

Mile 1307.5 | May 27, 2010

At the end of a long day -- on the first day into New Jersey, plans to camp out on a ridge were foiled by thunder, forcing a late-evening scramble to the nearest shelter, four miles north. Luckily the storms passed by, leaving me with spectacular misty sunset views.

Burn area

Mile 1456 | June 4, 2010

Misty trail and rock monolith

Mile 1485 | June 6, 2010

Arrived last night in Falls Village, CT, where I found... nothing... at all to eat. Asked a local family for dining suggestions, and could hardly believe my ears when I was invited over for dinner! Grilled chicken over pasta salad, delicious. After dinner I was treated to a performance of "Morris Dancing" — an old English tradition, performed in Falls Village only once per year — last night. Camped out behind a cafe where I ate breakfast this morning, then hit the trail in a drizzling rain. Just a short eight miles to Salisbury, CT, where I am refueling and spending the night. Hobbled from coffee shop to coffee shop in search of pancakes, which were eventually found after several smoothies, scones, and bagels. All wonderful. Some other hikers are rolling in throughout the day; hope to see some familiar faces. Big dinner tonight, then back at it full-time tomorrow. Three weeks in; I can hardly believe it. Having a blast so far!

Welcome to Massachusetts
